item.title: A couple of pointers about formal writing (very formal writing, perhaps)
item.description:
An occasional intake of prescriptivist grammar is invaluable (in other words, writing well and prolifically is usually a pain –).


Run-on sentence

Insufficient punctuation

* Specific agendas in media organisations lead to information being manipulated or hidden therefore individual research efforts are valuable.

   More information


Comma splice

A type of run-on sentence, the comma splice is characterised by the use of of too-weak punctuation forms; often, using a comma instead of a semi-colon or a period.

* Specific agendas in media organisations lead to information being manipulated or hidden, therefore individual research efforts are valuable.

   More information


Comma

Commas are useful for the purpose of coordinating phrases and clauses, facilitating the reading, and disambiguating. However, commas are also liable to underuse, as in the case of run-on sentences; misuse, as in the comma splice; and overuse, as it often happens with the Oxford comma.

   More information

Oxford comma

The Oxford, or serial, comma (namely, the comma preceding the word ‘and’ before the last item in a series) has the purpose of facilitating the reading and disambiguating. Where that purpose is not necessary, this comma is overused.

Find out more:

   Oxford University guide

   The Guardian guide

   More about overuse


Letter case after a colon

After a colon, lower case is recommended when a phrase or dependent clause is introduced (e.g., ‘They found a use for that jar: popping in some plastic flowers’), whereas upper case is recommended when an independent clause is introduced (e.g., ‘They found a use for that jar: They popped in some plastic flowers’).

   More information
